simplified_snt: Autonomous vehicles are a hot topic in both academia and industry right now.
More drones are being used in civilian and commercial areas, so they need to be able to work on their own.
Governments have rules about how high drones can fly. Because of this, people are looking into using roads to help guide drones.
We suggest a new approach to help drones fly safely through city streets. Our method uses imitation learning, where a drone learns to fly by copying an experienced pilot.
Our classifier is a fast 39-layered Inception model that uses tomographic reconstructions to detect roads in images.
Our system uses a specific architecture called Inception-v3. It's better than many others for imitating actions because it's simpler and more accurate.
The system was trained using data collected by flying a drone in urban and semi-urban areas. Experienced pilots with 6-8 years of experience captured the data.
We got permission from the right people to make sure collecting data wouldn't put pedestrians in danger.
We used a lot of drone data. We can now fly drones along roads without crashing or going off course. We're very accurate, at 98.44%.
The MAVNet system makes it possible for the drone to fly fast, reaching speeds of up to 6 meters per second.
We show the same results in this study and compare them to other top-performing methods for navigating with computer vision and machine learning.
Intelligent systems can help reduce accidents by recognizing traffic signs.
Self-driving cars need to recognize traffic and hand-held signs on streets.
Machine learning methods like Random Forest, SVM, and deep learning are used to identify traffic signs.
Some models do very well on a specific set of traffic sign pictures, but struggle with different ones.
We introduce a new approach that does well on many tests, beating the current best methods.
Our model uses blocks of convolutional layers with skip connections that get bigger and bigger.
Our system achieves high accuracy in recognizing German signs, scoring 99.33%. Additionally, it also excels in classifying Belgian traffic signs, with an accuracy of 99.17%.
We suggest a new way to represent information using a technique that uses less memory and computer power.
We present Ignition, a neural network that trains self-driving cars in virtual environments without restrictions.
The model uses a modified ResNet-18. It takes images of the front of a simulated F1 car and produces the best labels for steering, acceleration, and braking.
We don't teach the model to recognize road features like track outlines or car distances. Instead, we show that it can learn these features on its own.
We developed a new way to use a trained AI model for self-driving cars in a new environment. This method allows a computer model trained on one set of data to work well in a different set of data.
A special type of neural network, called a CNN, is used to control a vehicle. It takes a picture from the front camera and sends a command to steer the vehicle.
We use a CNN to learn steering commands and also to detect lane departures. To do this, we add a new module to the CNN that takes its output and uses it to determine the level of lane departure.

A CNN trained on one task is used to train another task. The new task, called the target network, takes the same output as the first task and learns to make a steering command for a different situation.
The steering commands from two networks are combined using a special method called LDL. This combined command is then used to control a car in a new environment.
We tested our method using two simulators. One, called TORCS, was used for the source domain, and the other, called GTAV, was used for the target domain.
Our experiment found that our new approach does a better job than others in controlling cars safely and reliably.
A major challenge in deep learning is having too little data to train models.
There are some datasets available for common problems like recognizing and classifying objects for self-driving cars. But, there's a lack of datasets for industrial robotics.

We previously trained a special kind of neural network called a CNN to recognize a robot's body in a picture and estimate the 3D positions of its joints using only a 2D image. However, it only worked for a specific type of robot made by Universal Robots.
We're improving our method to work with a new robot arm, the Kuka LBR iiwa. It looks different and has an extra joint.

We don't gather huge datasets again. Instead, we collect smaller sets with a few hundred frames each. We then use a technique called transfer learning to adapt a CNN trained on UR robots to work with a new robot that looks and sees things differently.

We found that transfer learning works well in this area. It needs smaller, better-prepared training data, trains faster, and is just as accurate as the original method. In some cases, it even performs better.
Automated decisions affect our choices and actions. This is a big issue in many areas, such as self-driving cars and organ transplants.
We use math to study and manage systems where self-driving cars take people around cities and move to where they're needed to keep service good.
We create a self-managing traffic system inside a closed network model with passengers leaving.
We used our ideas to create a reliable algorithm that adjusts things in real-time. We tested it in New York City using a robot with eight vehicles.
A study in New York found that around 8,000 robotic taxis, about 70% of the current number, could meet the city's taxi demand in Manhattan.
We add congestion to our original model. We then look at how self-driving cars affect traffic congestion overall.
This paper shows a clear way to manage self-driving cars and their impact on the environment. It's one of the first studies to look at the benefits of using robots to transport people.
The digital revolution is changing our economy and society.
This change can be very good, but it also comes with big dangers to our community.
Automation is moving beyond factories and cars. It's now coming to our daily lives.
We're at a critical moment. We must choose between a society where decisions are made by a few and enforced through rules or technology, or a society where everyone has a say and works together.
ICT helps with both, but the second one has economic and strategic advantages.
Human dignity, free choice, and democracy are under threat. I think we should strongly defend them. These principles are essential for a good society and also lead to greater success.
When self-driving cars become a reality, people won't worry about driving. They'll need new ways to stay entertained during their rides.
Content delivery is slow because of long communication times between cars and data centers.
We suggest using a deep learning-based caching system for self-driving cars. This system will use deep learning techniques and be deployed on a Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) network.
At DC, a special kind of artificial intelligence called Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) predicts the likelihood of certain content being asked for in specific areas.
To speed up processing, the output from a special computer (MLP) is sent to roadside units connected to Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) servers.
To make entertainment content more appealing to car passengers, we use a special type of AI called a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). This helps predict the age and gender of passengers.
The self-driving car can recognize what data it needs from the MEC server and store it locally.
We create a deep learning system for self-driving cars to improve entertainment services. Our goal is to reduce the time it takes to download content.
To solve the problem, we use a method called Block Successive Majorization-Minimization (BS-MM).
Our simulation results show that our predictions are accurate 98.04% of the time when it comes to what content needs to be stored in a self-driving car.

This paper explains how we created and tested a simple simulation of a stock market, called the Bristol Stock Exchange (BSE). It's based on a common way that real stock exchanges work, called a Limit Order Book (LOB).
Many big financial markets are now automated. This means that trading decisions, which used to be made by humans, are now made by fast computers.
Scientists study new financial markets, but it's hard because they can't experiment with the market while it's running. They have to use past data instead.
To create advanced trading systems, engineers need hands-on training in a realistic simulation.
BSE is used in a UK university for teaching and research. It's been used since 2012 and the code is available for free on GitHub.
This study looks at how stock prices change when companies release financial information about different things.
We focus on large numbers of documents that can't be easily grouped by their content beforehand.
We use a data mining technique called latent Dirichlet allocation to analyze topics.
We use a technique to quickly sort and categorize over 70,000 regulatory filings from US companies.
We examine how the stock market responds after the event.
Our research shows that different news stories have varying effects on the stock market.

We found that stock prices react strongly to certain news. This includes earnings reports, credit ratings, and updates on business strategy, the healthcare industry, and company mergers and acquisitions.
Our study shows how to organize financial reports and what topics often come before stock prices change.
This paper focuses on financial markets and trading systems used by banks.
Computers now allow international trade deals to happen very quickly, in just milliseconds. This wouldn't be possible without modern software.

Here's a simplified version of the text:

We'll explore the trading system's structure and how it connects with other important bank systems.

Humanoid robots have a problem. When they move or shake, it creates noise inside the robot from things like motors and fans. This noise makes it hard for the robot to understand what people are saying.
A new speech recognition system for robots is developed. This system can handle noise from the robot's own movements. It uses information about the robot's motor to improve speech recognition.
We focus on bottleneck features, which have worked well in deep neural network-based speech recognition systems.
We use motor on/off data along with acoustic features to train the first deep neural network.

The second deep neural network (DNN) uses two types of features: 

* Bottleneck features from the first DNN
* Acoustic features
Our method performs better than usual systems. It reduces phoneme error rate by 11% on the TIMIT database.
Researchers have suggested several methods to teach humanoid robots to perform household tasks, like controlling the robot remotely, learning from humans, and copying human actions.
Sensor-based robots can overcome challenges from unknown environments and uncertain models, making them more useful.
When robots do tasks that need human help, it's better to study how they interact with their surroundings using sensors, rather than telling them exactly where to move.
Social media lets people interact with many different opinions like never before.

They also spread false information by letting people choose what they want to read. This happens in two ways. First, people tend to believe what they already think is true (confirmation bias). Second, personalized news on phones and computers shows us only what we want to see, making it easy to believe what we already believe.
We still don't fully understand the balance between different factors.

We created a model where most people in a network update their beliefs fairly based on new information. However, a few people have a confirmation bias, which means they can reject news that doesn't match what they already believe.
We found that a simple way people form opinions can create long-lasting disagreements.
The model shows that agents who don't have biases act like they do because their biased neighbors limit their access to different information.

We studied how people's beliefs are distributed. We found a trade-off between how much people agree with each other and how much they believe what they want to believe. We tested our results using data from US counties about how the internet affects people's beliefs about global warming.
Our research shows that a little confirmation bias can actually help people be more accurate by keeping different ideas in a group.
When people have strong opinions, they tend to share information only with others who agree with them, which can lead to a decline in accuracy.
We explore the consequences of our model's results, pointing out the limitations of debunking methods and proposing new approaches to combat false information.
The World Wide Web changed how we get and share information.
People often choose information that supports their beliefs. This leads to groups of people who think the same way, ignoring information that disagrees.
In this situation, people work together to create and support their shared story. This makes it hard to prove it's wrong.

When people get their news online, a similar situation happens. Since 63% of people get news directly from social media, it's possible that increased polarization helps spread false information even more.
We study how Facebook users in Italy, France, Spain, and Germany are divided into groups with different views on news outlets.
We examine how people post, like, and comment on social media in different countries.
We look at how people choose which pages to interact with and how this leads to the formation of groups with similar views.
Italy is the most divided country, followed by France, Germany, and then Spain.
We developed a new way to use the Bounded Confidence Model to study how online communities form. We focused on how users interact with news and build trust with each other.
Our research shows that people trust the source of information online is crucial in preventing online users from becoming polarized.
For peer-to-peer networks, it's crucial to have a way to control how nodes use resources and prevent attacks like flooding and denial-of-service with spam messages.
We explore and compare methods for decentralized resource control used in cryptocurrency projects.
We use these methods to create a decentralized exchange for Namecoin names and other cryptocurrencies.
Monero and other memory-bound cryptocurrencies have made it possible to mine cryptocurrency using JavaScript in a web browser, which is a good alternative to using specialized mining equipment.

Here's a simplified version of the text:

"Cryptojacking is a new way of using computers without permission. Some websites secretly use visitors' computers to mine for cryptocurrencies. This happens without visitors knowing or agreeing."
We investigate a specific issue. To do this, we use a 3-step method. This helps us find and study cryptojacking on 1 million websites.
Cryptojacking is a common problem. About 1 in 500 websites secretly run a mining script.

We also did some extra research to learn more about cryptojacking. This included:

* Studying code features
* Estimating how much money hackers can make from mining
* Testing current methods to stop cryptojacking attacks
Modern blockchains have led to the creation of smart contracts. These are self-running programs that live on the blockchain.

Smart contracts are becoming very popular. They will be used in law, business, and government. These contracts are written in a special language, like Solidity, and then converted into a smaller code to run on a blockchain.
After being sent, the code runs automatically by a computer program that can do everything a human can do with a computer.
Smart contracts can be hacked because of poor programming methods, language issues, and faulty tools.
Smart contracts are also valuable targets, often worth a lot of cryptocurrency.
Developers and auditors need security tools that can look at the basic code of a program to find potential security problems.
We introduce Vandal, a tool to analyze the security of Ethereum smart contracts.
Vandal is a tool that takes Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) code and turns it into a format that's easier to understand.
The framework lets users describe security checks in a simple way. They write a security analysis in a special language called Souffle.
Vandal is fast and reliable. It can analyze almost all contracts (over 95%) in just 4.15 seconds. This is better than other tools like Oyente, EthIR, Mythril, and Rattle.
Bitcoin has become popular over the past decade. This has made it a target for bad people.
Digital techniques make it easy to tamper with images, which is causing concerns about image authenticity.
JPEG images are easy to alter without leaving a trace. As a result, researchers are actively studying how to detect tampering, such as double compression, interpolation, and rotation, in JPEG images.
Detecting image tampering and related operations using the same quantization matrix is still an open problem.
We want to catch images that have been tampered with. To do this, we're using a new method that looks at how images change when they're compressed and then decompressed.
We use learning classifiers to categorize things.
Our study shows that this method is very good at finding manipulated images and similar changes using the same matrix.
Time tampering is a major issue in digital forensics.
It's crucial to identify changes and recreate the original timeline of events.
Hackers can easily hide changes because they have many ways to do so.
Cloud computing and computer times can be changed by hackers.
Virtual machines can be easily attacked by their host computer because the host has more power.
It's crucial to keep track of time in a cloud, both for the hosts and guests. Make sure any changes to the timeline are noticeable.
"We examine the problems of keeping time accurate on cloud-based host and guest machines."
We present a new system to detect and fix problems with host and guest timing when they're compromised.
We tested our framework on a special computer program designed just for this purpose.
Our proposal is possible because of good results.
Identifying image editing operations is crucial in image forensics.
The tool analyzes an image's processing history and detects potential forgeries.
Several methods have been developed to identify various image editing techniques in a single system.
Operations need to be known beforehand during training.
In real-life forensic cases, it's often unclear what changes were made to an image.
We developed a new way to use deep learning to identify various image editing techniques.
"A deep neural network compares image patches in pairs, deciding if they're similar or different."
The network learns to recognize features that distinguish between image editing operations. This allows it to identify new editing operations it wasn't trained on.
Our experiment shows that the new method is good at identifying various image editing actions.
Digital assistants are getting more popular. When using these assistants, people often do many things at once.
DIANE is a digital assistant that helps doctors quickly find hospital information, such as medical records and staff data. It does this by using face recognition and live video feeds.
Research has shown that people often make decisions based on biases.
We studied how managers' biases affect team decisions and impact company performance.
In computer simulations, managers' decisions are affected by biases. These biases come from how complex the organization is and the incentives in place.
The results show how different biases working together and in different company settings impact company success.
We discovered that some mixed biases actually boost company performance, even though they hurt performance when they happen alone.
Should decision-making be as logical as possible?
Mobile robots need to understand their surroundings to move safely in changing environments.
Most robots, including humanoids and small wheeled robots, use flat areas.
For human-like robots, a simple 2D map isn't enough. They can step over and onto objects, so they need information about height.
Dynamic obstacles make things harder because they can cause problems later on.
We developed a system that finds flat areas in 3D maps and identifies moving barriers.
Our system uses this data to make maps that help plan routes quickly and use minimal computer power.
Our system can perform one step of 3D footstep planning in under 10 milliseconds, making it suitable for real-time use.
An autonomous robot looks for a person to help with a task.
A difficult problem arises when the person moves around because the robot's view is limited and the environment's structure makes it hard to see.
We developed a new approach to predict the likelihood of a user being visible at any location in a space using computer simulations.
We consider the time it takes for the robot to reach possible locations and visibility limitations when calculating the most effective places to search.
The robot can select the next search spot with the highest chance of finding the user.
Our tests in different computer simulations show that our method takes less time to find the answer compared to a simple approach that uses extra information.
People often follow familiar routes to get to specific places where they need help from a mobile robot.
The robot may not always follow the same path as a human because there are often better routes available.
We want to predict where a person will move and use that info to help a robot make smart decisions.
Humans may be blocked by obstacles or the robot's limited view, making it harder to know where they are and where they'll go next.
Our approach handles situations where the human is blocked by explicitly considering occlusions in the reward function. This makes the robot focus on actions that put the human in its view.

Our method helps robots find shorter paths. We tested it in simulations and real-world scenarios. It works better than a technique that always follows the user closely and can handle obstacles getting in the way.
We present a method to help robots move quickly and safely through messy indoor spaces.
We suggest calculating the density of obstacles near detected objects and using this information to predict how hard it will be for the robot to move through areas it can't see yet.
The robot plans its path considering the predicted costs. This helps it move more efficiently and avoid getting stuck in cluttered areas.
Our method helps a robot move quickly through messy areas and finishes tasks faster than usual methods that don't predict anything.
We created a navigation system for humanoid robots to move around on their own in messy, unfamiliar spaces.
Our system uses a camera on a robot to figure out where it is and what's around it. It corrects mistakes in the robot's movement and creates a map of the environment.
Our system finds a series of safe movements, including steps and body actions, to guide a robot to a specific location.
We created a new way to quickly detect collisions between a robot and obstacles. It considers the robot's shape and the obstacles' shapes.
Our system helps a humanoid robot, like the Nao, navigate easily through messy spaces and overcome tough obstacles.
We developed a new way to accurately adjust a humanoid robot's movement model using only its single camera.
Our method finds the key values of a complete model, which includes the slight adjustments to joint angles for the entire body, including legs, as well as camera settings.
We created a way to pick a few important settings for calibration that balances the number of data points and how accurate they are.
Our method for choosing the right settings gets better results than picking them at random.
Our system only needs a few settings to get accurate results.
We developed a general optimization method. Our implementation is online and can be easily adapted to various humanoid robots.

Here is a simplified version of the text:

We're proposing a new idea for a lab automation drone.
A robotic arm is attached to a flying robot.
A special device on a drone lets it pick up small things like micro-arrays and test tubes used in fast testing systems.
A new drone could help improve existing high-temperature superconducting (HTS) operations.
A 6-DOF arm and gripper design is shown.

A novel approach to predict protein-protein interactions (PPIs) uses a combination of sequence-based and structure-based features. The method, called PROTEUS, integrates information from protein sequences, 3D structures, and evolutionary relationships to identify potential interaction sites. 

PROTEUS uses a machine learning algorithm to analyze these features and predict whether a protein-protein interaction is likely to occur. The algorithm was trained on a dataset of known PPIs and tested on a separate set of interactions.

The results show that PROTEUS outperforms existing methods in predicting PPIs, with an accuracy of 92%. The approach also identifies new potential interaction sites that were not previously known.

In conclusion, PROTEUS is a powerful tool for predicting protein-protein interactions, with high accuracy and ability to identify new potential interactions.
Robot companions are becoming more popular.
Humanoid robots may not be stable enough for certain tasks.
Small people still fall often.
A small robot has been given wheels to help it move quickly and steadily.
A robot can change from walking to rolling when needed.
DARwIn-OP is a robot that looks like a human. It's used to test and evaluate new ideas.
This study explores the idea of using a small humanoid robot to be a companion. The robot can pick up different toys when told to do so by voice command.

Drones with network connections have many uses. They can be used for:

* Surveillance
* Recording videos
* Operations
* Entertainment and advertising
* Sending signals
* Transportation
* Delivery
Some apps and services need video recording to work.
Big drones are used alone for tasks, while smaller ones work together in groups or teams.
Small drones are useful in many civilian jobs.
Small drones are being used for group flights, entertainment, and sending signals. This is leading to the development of networked drones.
We suggest a system to control drone formations in real-time for group displays.
A study found that drones can form patterns to convey messages clearly.
The internet and mobile devices have changed our daily lives quickly.
Many companies are moving their business online.
Digital transformation is changing the way businesses market and advertise.
Many companies are using digital marketing to promote their brands and products. This is because of the popularity of Key Opinion Leaders, social media, and selling products in many different ways.
Digital marketing tools are diverse and need to be chosen wisely. Consider many factors when selecting a tool.
We created a new method to help industry professionals evaluate and choose the best digital marketing tools.
Our method makes it easier to choose digital marketing tools and helps marketers achieve their goals.
This study looks at how small tourism businesses use digital marketing.
The study explores how technology tools help a company improve its performance.
The study looks at marketing in a new way, focusing on the skills involved. This helps us better understand how tourism marketing works online.
Companies' digital marketing skills are improved when they use ICT technology.

Four key skills develop when using these tools:

1. Problem-solving: You learn to tackle complex issues.
2. Critical thinking: You improve your ability to analyze information.
3. Collaboration: You develop skills to work effectively with others.
4. Adaptability: You become more comfortable with change and new situations.
The study shows that using digital tools helps small tourism businesses not only stay in the digital marketing game, but also take charge of it.

Big data lets us collect, store, and analyze huge amounts of information quickly and cheaply. This helps in many areas, such as:

* More efficient marketing
* Better healthcare
* Environmental protection
* National security
The current rules for protecting privacy are being stretched thin due to big data and its technology and business practices.
As we interact with artificial agents without human help, their ability to act on their own and do complex tasks raises important questions about the law and philosophy.
The focus on machines is taking attention away from important discussions about ethics in data use. This includes issues like privacy, fairness, and preventing unfair treatment.
The machine can make ethical problems worse, help with them, or just highlight them. Ultimately, humans are responsible.
Policymakers should create rules for fair and ethical data use.

Guidelines will focus on using legal and technical methods to hide data. They will also identify unfair or illegal behavior, define types of harm to privacy and non-privacy, and help individuals access data in a clear format.
Smart speakers with voice interaction are becoming more common. As a result, people will get used to talking to them.

Speech recognition and natural language processing have gotten better, but users still sometimes get errors. This can be frustrating, like when it says "cannot understand" or "no music" when you ask for it.
When an error message appears, the smart speaker should give a helpful and correct answer.
Chinese smart speaker brands have different ways to respond to users. The main differences are whether they apologize or not, and whether they use humor or stay neutral.
We studied how users prefer to handle errors in two situations: when they can't understand something and when a requested audio resource is missing.
We measured two important factors: customer satisfaction and how sincere they felt the company's response was.
People were happier and thought the smart speaker was more honest when it apologized for mistakes.
When there's no audio to play, humor doesn't affect how satisfied or sincere people seem.
When people can't understand what's being said, they think the speaker is less sincere if they use funny expressions.
Smart speakers struggle to tell apart human voices from computer-generated voices.

A way to determine if a voice command is coming from a human or a machine is needed.

To identify the sender of voice commands to a smart speaker, a method is required.

We suggest a system to protect smart speakers from fake voice attacks when no one is home. It includes a speaker and microphone array to detect if a person is nearby. This could be added to smart speakers in the future.

Amazon's Echo and Apple's Siri are popular voice assistants. But they only work with a few languages. This means that people who speak different languages, including both native and non-native English speakers, can't fully use these assistants.
We studied how 20 people used the Google Home speaker. They were native English speakers and non-native English speakers. We wanted to know how they differed in using the speaker.
Native English speakers had better experiences using the device. They had more positive interactions.
Users' English skills matter when using voice assistants.
This study's results can help designers and developers create voice user interfaces that work well in many languages and understand different voices.

Scientists used a special method to study and compare different types of compounds that can help create new medicines. They looked at four groups: drug molecules, compounds tested for new drugs, building blocks for creating new compounds, and non-medicinal molecules.
The shapes of the drug molecules and the high-throughput screening compounds are different. This is because the screening compounds are more similar to non-drug molecules.
"Using pharmacophore profiles can help improve the chances of finding good leads by optimizing compound selection and library design."
"Using special computer language, we can make experiment descriptions understandable by machines."
Scientists write protocols in simple and clear language, making it hard for computers to understand and analyze them.

We can use an ontology to capture important information by making statements. These statements are like "A is related to B in a certain way" and are written as three parts: subject, relationship, and object.

"Assays can be searched, grouped, labeled, and judged in many ways, similar to other parts of drug discovery computer work."

(Note: ROUGE, SARI, and BLEU scores are metrics used to evaluate the quality of machine translation or text summarization. Since I'm simplifying text for English-speaking college students, I'm not aiming for high scores in these metrics. However, I've tried to use simple words and short sentences to make the text easy to understand.)
The BioAssay Ontology (BAO) helps organize important words related to bioassays. It has a clear structure with categories that can be connected to each other.
Next-generation sequencing makes huge amounts of data. This data includes many reads and samples.
After initial analysis, scientists use free and open-source software tools to further process the data. Each tool does one specific task to get closer to the final answer.
Bioinformaticians need to combine tools, organize data and extra details, write notes, and make sure results can be repeated.

We used a statistical tool called SPSS Clementinel 2.0 to find connections between:

* Etiology (the cause of a disease) and traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)
* Syndromes (patterns of symptoms) and TCM
* Symptoms and TCM
The Apriori algorithm helps find patterns in old Chinese medicine treatments for the flu.
Finding bacteria that don't respond to antibiotics in environmental samples is crucial for human health and food safety.
Next-generation sequencing helps us find genetic differences and connect them to physical traits in humans and other animals.

A new method, Genetic Polymorphisms Assignments (GPA), uses a Bayesian approach to identify the mix of different bacteria in a sample. This method reduces mistakes in identifying single nucleotide variations (SNVs) and improves accuracy.
CRISPR-Cas is a popular tool for changing genes.
Unexpected problems can happen when a nuclease is active for a long time.
Anti-CRISPR proteins can stop CRISPR-Cas from working. This could help us use CRISPR-Cas better for gene editing, especially for treating diseases.
Studying these proteins further can help scientists understand how bacteria and phages have evolved together.
We need to gather and combine data on different kinds of anti-CRISPRs.
The CRISPR/Cas9 system is a powerful tool for changing specific parts of our DNA. It can edit genes (change the genetic code) or control gene activity (without changing the code).
Designing CRISPR tools needs efficient and specific single guide RNAs (sgRNAs).
It's still tough to do this because many factors need to be considered.
CRISPR is a popular area of research because it's good at making precise changes to DNA.
Gene editing techniques have been created to change genes. These techniques have different goals.
Scientists can precisely edit DNA. They can cut and fix specific parts of the DNA, allowing them to remove, fix, turn off, or turn on genes.
CRISPR/Cas9 is a powerful tool for high-content screens because it's easy to prepare and use.
Gene editing might help with healthcare distribution problems.
Making future generations healthier could align with public health goals. This could benefit individuals and communities, and if successful, be considered a public benefit.
To create better future generations, we need In Vitro Fertilisation and Pre-implantation Genetic Diagnosis.
Women's role in a positive situation has been ignored by those who support it.
The discussion about the moral responsibilities of future generations doesn't mention women, but it implies that women might be morally obligated to use IVF to have children.
Future generations will be gendered unless a new way to grow babies outside the womb is created.
Women and men need to work together to solve these difficult problems.
There's no clear agreement on the pros and cons of editing the human genome. However, it's crucial to understand the role of women in this process.
The CRISPR-Cpf1 tool has been used to make precise changes to genes.
The CRISPR-Cpf1 system works better with some gRNA sequences than others.
Scientists used a machine learning tool called SVM to make predictions about how well a specific piece of genetic code (gRNA) works.
The first web service app, CRISPR-DT, helps design optimal gRNAs for CRISPR-Cpf1. It considers both target efficiency and specificity.
Autonomous cars need to understand the driving scene in detail.

To solve this problem, we need to identify important features in stereo images taken by a vehicle's cameras. We do this by grouping urban scene elements into categories that are easy to understand, such as streets, buildings, people, cars, signs, and more.
A new way is suggested to combine rough 3D map information with stereo image classification.

We propose a new way to combine two types of data: pixel-wise image segmentation from a deep learning model and depth information from stereo images. This combination includes both general depth estimates and specific label information.
The team tested their method using a dataset with labeled information in urban settings.
"This method improves the accuracy of identifying basic elements in city scenes. It does better than just using a computer vision algorithm to break down images into individual pixels."
Self-driving cars are now more common on roads. They aim to make transportation safer and more efficient.

Making self-driving cars reliable on the road needs a lot of software testing. This should be done on special simulators that mimic real-life situations, with multiple cars and pedestrians interacting with the self-driving vehicle.
It's crucial to test self-driving software in many tough simulated driving situations.
The best way to create driving scenarios, used by top self-driving car companies, currently involves human help.

We suggest using a method called Bayesian optimization to create fake scenarios for self-driving cars. These scenarios will show how poorly designed or trained self-driving systems can cause accidents with virtual pedestrians and vehicles.

Protein-protein docking is hard because it's hard to pick the best solutions from many possibilities.

PROCOS uses a combination of two complex property distributions, one for real complexes and one for false complexes, along with a support vector machine (SVM) for analysis.

Cookies help keep track of user sessions, personalize experiences, and verify identities. They also monitor user behavior.

The European Union has a new rule called GDPR. It makes sure that personal data is kept private and secure. This means that companies can't store, access, or use your personal data without your permission.
Large amounts of data can cause problems with business processes. These processes are often complicated, which can lead to mistakes that violate GDPR rules.
This paper talks about the problems and important parts of following the GDPR rules when using simple solutions.
We suggest a step-by-step approach to following GDPR rules using online tools that analyze business processes.
We tested our tool on many big log files from a real situation. It works well and uses system resources wisely.
This idea is useful for following data protection rules in small steps.

In today's digital world, businesses need to handle personal data. The European Union (EU) has rules to protect this data. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a new law that helps keep EU citizens' personal information safe from being shared without permission.
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is changing how companies handle data privacy. This means they must update their business processes to follow GDPR rules.
Many companies struggle to find privacy problems in business processes because not much has been done to make it easy.
We're going to analyze the main privacy rules in GDPR and suggest ways to include these rules in business process models.

We use a specific way to draw business processes (BPMN) to make it easy to see all the rules about privacy in those processes. This helps us ensure that the processes follow the rules of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Availability is important.

Measuring how similar words mean is important in many computer programs that understand human language.
Term similarity is usually thought of as a two-way relationship.

Some words have special relationships with each other, but these relationships aren't always the same in both directions. This makes it hard to use simple measures of similarity to identify these relationships.
Directional similarity is a more general concept than symmetric similarity. It's often more useful in certain natural language processing tasks.
Current similarity measures have a problem. They can't easily compare large amounts of text from the internet.
We suggest a new way to measure similarity that looks at both language and non-language features.
We test our method on word similarity, achieving the best results on several datasets.

Our method is good at finding connections between words and phrases, both those that are similar and those that are specific to direction. This helps improve search results and suggest better search terms.

We developed a new way to find lung tumors using a special filter. This filter helps identify nodules that were hard to detect in previous computer-aided detection (CAD) systems.

In CT images, a large area is first made clearer using an active contour filter. This type of filter is designed to enhance contrast and has a flexible shape.
"The kernel shape has closed curves that join together at moving points. These points move back and forth to surround a large area."
ACF's final result is the difference between the brightest pixel on a moving filter and the pixel at the filter's center.
The PET images were changed to black and white to find areas with higher activity.
We combined the results, then removed false positives using 21 important features and three special machines.
We tested our new method with 100 pictures of the body taken with PET/CT scans.
Most nodules that were previously missed were correctly identified.
Our method can help detect lung tumors from PET/CT images.
E-commerce growth and online payments have made credit card fraud a big problem worldwide.
Machine learning is being used to detect credit card fraud.

There are several challenges in this field, including:

* Limited access to public data
* Imbalanced data sets (where one class is much larger than others)
* Different types of fraudulent behavior
We compare three machine learning methods: Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression. They help detect fraud in real-life credit card transactions.
To fix uneven class sizes, we use a technique called SMOTE.
Fraud patterns change often. We're testing how machine learning algorithms can learn from new data to keep up with these changes.
We assess the techniques using two important measures: precision and recall.

We need to carefully examine the gene editing experiment after it's finished.

The method uses new data to measure and identify:

* Insertions (adding DNA)
* Deletions (removing DNA)
* Homologous recombination (swapping DNA sequences)
CRISPR Genome Analyzer gives a report on the chosen location. This report shows how much editing was done and what changes were made.

"The platform maps reads, finds and locates insertions and deletions, calculates efficiency and provides a report with all the results."

Note: I've used simpler vocabulary and shorter sentences while keeping the key words from the original text.

The CRISPR/Cas9 system has made many discoveries, but it's still hard to prevent mistakes and make the editing process more effective.
Past research on guide RNA focused on DNA characteristics.
Some DNA features haven't been studied yet. But we can learn about them by looking at protein properties, like how disordered they are and how conserved their sequences are.

We used a method called Maximal-Relevance-Minimal-Redundancy to examine these features.
We used a combination of incremental feature selection and support vector machines to pick the most important features. This allowed us to build an optimal classifier.
We extracted 152 important features and used them to create the best classifier, a support vector machine.
This classifier got the best results, with a score of 0.355.
Scientists studied the best features in detail to understand their biological properties.

Fake news is a big problem. Social media companies struggle to detect it.
The term "fake news" is hard to define because it can include intentionally false stories, misleading information, satire, or even just stories someone dislikes.
To solve the issue, we need to define and illustrate it clearly.
We created a dataset of fake news and satire articles that are carefully labeled and verified. For fake news, we also included articles that correct the misinformation.

We analyzed the articles to identify major themes. We found that some articles strongly support or criticize a person, spread conspiracy theories, contain racist ideas, or question the credibility of trusted sources.
We're making this dataset available for research. Our analysis shows that the language in the dataset is useful for classifying things.

The internet is unique because its technical features have created a free and uncontrolled space for information.
We've overestimated the internet skills of many young people, leaving them vulnerable to online risks.
Young people are easily influenced by false information on the internet, like misinformation about health and conspiracy theories.
A solution for digitally illiterate young people is a re-education program.
I'll analyze these claims to show how our research approach has influenced what we say about young people online.
I think we're mistakenly focusing on finding groups with problems online. This has led us to unfairly judge young people and the internet for not being good at finding reliable information online.
If we follow the common view, we blame the internet for spreading misinformation. This thinking says technology is the main cause of people being misinformed.
Researchers often focus on young people's problems, which leads to outdated ideas about youth being physically or biologically flawed.
Young people's problems are often blamed on their parents' job or ethnicity. However, this approach reduces young people to helpless victims of unfair systems.

My research takes a different approach. I'm not using methods that just confirm young people's limited power in society, like tests and questionnaires. These methods often label people as "unskilled" or "skilled", which is too simple.
Young people's social status affects how they see themselves. They're not just passive, they're actively trying to figure out their place in the world.
I redefine the traditional concepts of true information, false information, and misleading information as constantly changing and influenced by social factors.
I put this uncertain information in the context of how power affects what we consider true in our society, as described by philosopher Michel Foucault.
I study how young people use information by breaking it down into smaller parts and combining different research methods, including both in-depth interviews and online observations.
I studied how youth interact with information online. My research looked at how different factors, such as the environment and social media, affect their behavior.
My research suggests that we can't blame the internet, young people, or their economic situation for why and how young people use the internet for information.
I searched for a framework that explains how technology, people, and society are connected.
This study explores how young people use the internet based on the opportunities and limitations they face in school and beyond.
Learning new skills is important, but it's even more important to learn them in the right social setting.
The environment around us affects what skills are considered normal, encouraged, and praised.
This thesis explores how young people use the internet, despite the concerns of others who want to control how it's used.

Young people's internet use is not entirely free. They don't always think deeply about their online actions. However, they do use the internet in complex ways that help them understand themselves and society's norms.

My research shows that young people's internet use comes from the differences between what they want to do online, what they've learned to do, what they've been taught to do, and what's allowed. These differences play out in their everyday social situations.
This research project focuses on understanding how young people use the internet in their daily lives, rather than just testing their digital skills with questionnaires and tests.
Young people's relationships with technology have significant effects.
We're no longer assuming young people know what they're doing. Instead, we're seeking proof to support our intervention methods.
We should reconsider how we explain why some young people struggle with technology and have unequal access to it. Otherwise, our efforts to help them might not work or even make things worse.

We created a system called GRIS to help scientists at NIH analyze patient data, combining genetic and physical characteristics to find the causes of rare diseases.

Our system helps with clinical genomic data that has labels for medical conditions using a standard language system called Human Phenotype Ontology.

GRIS uses a tool called PhenoTips to collect medical records and family history. This information is linked to genetic data stored in a tool called seqr, developed by the Broad Institute. This helps identify the cause of genetic variants.

We've modified two programs to meet NIH security rules. We've also made it possible to connect patient records across programs in a controlled way. Additionally, we've created different levels of access so that research groups can decide who can edit patient records and view personal information.

A big challenge for shared medical data centers is to make data openly available for many researchers, while also letting researchers control who can access patient data based on their research goals and following medical sharing rules.
We created a way to share policies made by researchers and clinicians. This will help more people use the system.
We created a system to match patient IDs and send automatic alerts to share patient information.

We developed a new way to automatically measure Tree-in-Bud patterns in respiratory infections.
Our new method is built on earlier work that uses a computer to find and follow patterns in lung tissue images.

We developed a new way to measure tumors. It works on a small scale, looking at specific areas of the tumor detected by a computer system. We compare the size of these areas to how radiologists rate the tumor's size.

We did an experiment using 94 chest CT scans. The scans showed:

The agreement between observers and computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) is high for HPIV and NTM cases. The strength of this agreement is 82.4% for HPIV and 80.1% for NTM, and both are statistically significant.

To ensure good service for all new users, packet-switched networks need to provide consistent quality. A new scheduling strategy called network proportional fairness scheduling (nPFS) helps achieve this goal. It combines several factors, including network performance, user needs, and fairness, to control traffic and meet multiple goals. Simulations show that this strategy works well, especially for ensuring good quality for different types of services.

When designing a system that does things at the same time, fairness is often considered at a specific level of the system. This leads to different types of fairness, such as fairness for transitions, objects or processes, and fairness for actors.
Fairness can be combined by making clear how it depends on specific parts of a system.

We suggest a new way to check if a system meets certain rules. Our method uses two main parts: a framework that looks at states and events, and an algorithm that checks these rules in real-time. These rules are based on fairness, which means that certain actions or conditions must happen or be met.
This tool checks if certain events happen at the right time, taking into account fairness rules that affect moving parts like new processes starting.

Banks lose a lot of money each year due to credit card fraud. To prevent this, they focus on detecting credit card fraud.

We studied how an ensemble makes decisions. We came up with three ways for it to vote: being very positive, very negative, or considering both.
The model combines the predictions of multiple models using three different approaches: optimistic, pessimistic, and weighted voting.
We used a real dataset of credit card transactions from a major Turkish bank to test the performance of three methods: optimistic, pessimistic, and weighted voting in a group of models.

The results show that:

The original text describes the concept of "non-locality" in quantum mechanics. This phenomenon suggests that particles can be instantaneously connected, regardless of their physical distance. This means that measuring the state of one particle can instantly affect the state of another, even if they are separated by large distances. This concept challenges our classical understanding of space and time.

The theory of non-locality was first proposed by Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen in 1935. They argued that quantum mechanics was incomplete and needed to be revised. Later, John Bell developed a mathematical framework to test the concept of non-locality. His work showed that the phenomenon was real and could be observed.

Today, scientists have successfully demonstrated non-locality in various experiments. For example, they have created entangled particles that can instantaneously communicate with each other. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of the universe and the nature of reality.

Key words: non-locality, quantum mechanics, entangled particles, Einstein, Podolsky, Rosen, John Bell.

Pages are grouped based on their topics and the groups of people interested in them. These groups are (a) alternative sources of information (covering topics ignored by science and mainstream media); (b) online political activism; and (c) mainstream media.
We found that attention patterns are similar, regardless of the type of information. This means that false claims, like conspiracy theories, can spread as easily as other information.

Daniel Pipes examines conspiracy theories in the West and their harmful effects.

If someone tells you not to believe what you read in the news, "Conspiracy" is a fascinating report that will surprise you.

Big Data has great potential for new discoveries, groundbreaking ideas, and even artificial intelligence.
We're surrounded by lots of data. People want to find patterns, even if they're not really there. This leads to a lot of useless data analysis, false "facts" being spread, and misleading graphics.
A lot of false information has been spreading quickly across social media without being controlled.
Online misinformation is a growing problem. Social news observatories can help researchers, journalists, and the public understand how real and fake news spreads.
Fake news, rumors, and conspiracy theories are examples.

We look at how people unknowingly support conspiracy theories by studying how groups move.

When people respond to false information, they're more likely to be attracted to parts of the screen that show a competing response, like "TRUE" for a conspiracy theory.

Online social media spreads conspiracy theories, fake news, and unproven claims quickly and uncontrollably.

We examine the statistical patterns of false information spread through social media.

We used a special type of math called Extreme Value Theory to study extremely popular online posts. We found that these posts appear at random times, and the time between each post is random and follows a specific pattern.
We use Bayesian methods to measure the uncertainty around the rate of events in a Poisson process.
We can calculate the probability of a post getting more than a certain number of shares within a specific time period.
Fake news, rumors, and conspiracy theories spread quickly on social media.
One idea is that social media, which are often separated into similar groups, may be a place where misinformation spreads easily.
Fact-checking can help stop misinformation, but it's not always effective. This is because people often choose to believe what they want to and have limited attention.

Factual verification is effective at containing misinformation when:

Factual verification is timely, accurate, and accessible. It must be done quickly to stop misinformation from spreading. The information must be correct and reliable, and people must be able to easily find it.

Factual verification is more effective when it is done by trusted sources, such as experts or fact-checking organizations. People are more likely to believe information from sources they trust.

Factual verification works best when it is done in a way that is easy to understand. Technical jargon or complex information can be confusing and may not be effective at stopping misinformation.

Factual verification can also be effective when it is done in a way that is engaging and interactive. For example, using social media or online platforms to share factual information can be more effective than simply posting it on a website.

Additionally, factual verification is more effective when it is done in a way that is collaborative. For example, when experts and fact-checking organizations work together to verify information, it can be more effective than when one person or organization tries to do it alone.

Finally, factual verification is more effective when it is done in a way that is transparent and accountable. People should be able to see how information was verified and who was involved in the process.
We consider three factors: people avoiding information because of network isolation, forgetting things over time, and checking facts to verify information.
We look at a model that shows how two types of epidemics spread on a network. This network is split into two groups: people who easily believe things (gullible) and people who are skeptical.

Computer simulations and math show that a network where people are more separate helps spread false information only if people tend to forget quickly. But if people forget slowly, this type of network doesn't make a difference.
This discovery can help create ways to reduce misinformation online and make people aware of the dangers.
When a crisis happens, social media sites become very busy.
This activity creates a mix of text and images. It helps first responders see what people care about and understand how citizens feel.
Researchers have studied text to understand public sentiment and themes during events. However, few have looked at visual themes on social networks, such as images, and how people feel about them.
We studied Facebook posts about the 2015 Paris terror attacks to see how images and words made people feel.
We used advanced image summarization methods to find common visual patterns in pictures that aren't mentioned in the text.
We found false information and conspiracy theories in popular image searches, but not in text searches. This is important for first responders to know.
After the attacks, people wrote negative things online. But, images shared online made people feel positive.
We know of no other big study on images shared on social media during a crisis.
Online social networks changed how people get news and form opinions. They're now a target for bad actors who spread false information and try to influence people.

It's crucial for our society to have a way to verify information shared on social media.
Using computer tools can greatly help validate many things at once.

Limited research has focused on understanding events through images shared on social media.

We suggest a simple and automated 3-step process that uses advanced computer vision methods to get important details from images that people can understand.
We linked themes and emotions to pictures, and studied over 57,000 images about the Paris Attacks.
We found common visual patterns in images that couldn't be detected through words.
We found misleading information and conspiracy theories in popular image topics, but not in user-written text.
After the attacks, people shared negative messages. But the images they shared made them feel positive.
Mining images from social media during a crisis or big news event can add a lot to what we know about the event.

We study groups of Twitter and Facebook users who waste time reading fake news from websites that target US military personnel and veterans with false information and conspiracy theories about military and national security.

Bot detection is important because it can have significant consequences.
Bots have been used to influence elections, manipulate the stock market, and spread false information about vaccines.
Most methods to detect bots focus on individual accounts. They analyze many social media posts and use information about the network, timing, and emotions expressed.

We created a new way to use a deep neural network to detect bots on Twitter. Our method uses a special type of neural network called LSTM, which looks at both what the tweet says and information about the user who posted it.
We propose a method to create a large dataset with labeled data from a small amount of labeled data (around 3,000 examples of complex Twitter bots).
Our system can accurately identify bots and humans from just one tweet, with a high accuracy rate of 96%.
We used the same approach to detect bots at the account level. Our method is very accurate, correctly identifying nearly all bots with an accuracy score of 99%.
Our system beats the best previous results while using only a few easy-to-understand features, and it works well even with limited training data.

Recent studies have found that word embeddings often contain biases like gender and racial biases.

Previous research has some limitations. It doesn't look at how biases are consistent across different things like:

* Types of computer models used
* Kinds of text being analyzed

We studied biases in word meanings found in word vectors. We looked at how consistent these biases are across different languages, types of texts, and ways of creating word vectors.
We study how biases from one language are copied into another when we use the same neural network model for both languages.

Our research found some surprising results. For example, different word-encoding methods can make biases more noticeable or less noticeable. We also found that content created by users may be less biased than information from encyclopedias.
We want our research to inspire studies on bias in computer language and help create methods to reduce bias.
Word embeddings often show biases. For example, they may favor men over women or certain races over others.

Current research has some limitations. It doesn't look at how biases are consistent across different areas, such as:

* Types of computer models used
* Types of texts analyzed
* Different languages
We examine biases in word meanings represented in computer language models. We look at how often these biases appear in different languages, types of text, and model types.
We study how language biases are shared between languages in word embeddings, showing how biases can be transferred from one language to another when using NLP models.

Our research found some surprising results. For example, different word-association models can make biases stronger or weaker. Additionally, content created by users may be less biased than information found in encyclopedias.
Our goal is to encourage research on bias in natural language processing and help create methods to reduce bias.
Some popular datasets for understanding language have a problem. They are biased towards the second part of a sentence.
Adversarial learning can help models focus on important information and ignore biases in the data.
We test if using adversarial learning in Natural Language Inference (NLI) helps models learn representations without bias towards one side of an argument.
Our research shows that using adversarial learning can reduce bias in the learned representations, with only a small decrease in accuracy.
Software development has a lack of gender diversity, especially among technical leaders.
Scientists and experts have worked hard to understand issues and find answers.
Many studies on software engineering overlook hidden gender biases.
The study looked into whether experienced software developers have unconscious gender biases against women in the field, and if these biases affect their decision-making.
Our research looked at 142 software engineers from seven companies. We found some worrying results.
Software engineers, both men and women, have unconscious biases. They often link tech jobs and leadership roles with men, not women. They also link women with home and family responsibilities.
People often act on their unconscious gender biases, making gender-neutral decisions, even when they're good at avoiding obvious gender biases.
Researchers have studied models that explain how agents make decisions based on biases: instead of choosing the best option, they act in ways that are not optimal because of a personal preference.
Researchers have mostly looked at an agent with one behavioral flaw, seeing how this flaw affects the outcome.
Decisions can be influenced by many biases at once.

Multiple biases interact to produce the overall outcome in a complex way. Each bias has its own impact, but they also combine and amplify each other. For example, confirmation bias can strengthen the effect of availability heuristic, making it more likely that people will remember and rely on information that supports their existing beliefs. At the same time, availability heuristic can amplify the impact of confirmation bias, making it even harder to consider alternative perspectives. Additionally, cognitive dissonance can also play a role, making people more resistant to changing their beliefs even when faced with contradictory evidence. As a result, multiple biases can create a cumulative effect, making it challenging to make informed decisions.

We're looking at decisions when two biases work together. The first bias is called present bias, which means we value things we have to pay for now more than things we have to pay for later. The second bias is called sunk-cost bias, which means we consider costs we've already paid for when making decisions about the future.
We created a theoretical model to understand how two biases work together. Our model shows that certain natural behaviors can happen when both biases are present.
Our model distinguishes between two types of agents. One type is aware of its biases and is sophisticated. The other type is not aware of its biases and is naive.
We found that the two biases interact in a complicated way. Sometimes, they cancel each other out. Other times, they make each other stronger.
Our model shows that planning for an agent aware of biases is a difficult problem, but it can be solved more easily if we make some assumptions.

"This algorithm breaks down the solution space of an optimization problem into smaller groups, called subspaces, and there are Q of them."
Each subspace has a certain number of particles. There are Q separate groups of particles, and each group searches its own space independently.
To make search results more diverse and thorough, particles in each group are started at random locations using a chaotic sequence.
"Our experiments show that the algorithm converges quickly and works well in complex problems with many variables."

A robot has trouble catching a moving target when it doesn't know the target's path or speed, and those things change quickly. This is especially hard when there are many obstacles around.
A new algorithm helps a robot catch a moving target by following short, straight lines.
The algorithm starts by predicting the point where the robot and target will intersect, assuming they both move in straight lines.
A robot quickly creates a route to a target point using a new algorithm inspired by ants.
A robot moves along a planned route while keeping track of its target.
When the robot notices the target has moved, it recalculates the interception point and updates its path.
The robot will keep tracking the moving target until it catches up.
The simulation results show that the algorithm works well. It can catch a moving target while moving a short distance, even with obstacles, and the target's path is straight or curved.

We examine a new version of a communication model that deals with confidential messages in a broadcast setting.
The transmitter sends two messages: a secret message and a public message to receiver 1.
We want to keep the secret message hidden from receiver 2. We don't need receiver 2 to perfectly understand the public message.

Here's a simplified version of the text:

A more flexible approach to handling non-confidential messages might be a better model. This model doesn't require both receivers to decode the non-confidential message.

Measuring how much we don't know:

We can describe how well we can send secret and public messages using three numbers: R1, Re, and Rp.

* R1 is the rate of secret messages
* Re is the rate of mistakes in our messages
* Rp is the rate of public messages

We're looking at a special kind of communication system called a Generalized Multiple Access Channel (GMAC). Two users want to send information to a destination. They both have two types of messages: common information that both users want to share, and private information that only one user wants to send.
This channel is similar to a multiple access channel (MAC). However, both users not only send but also receive information.
Users think the other user is trying to listen in and wants to keep their private information hidden.
The secrecy of confidential information is measured by how easily it can be misinterpreted.
"The important measurement is a set of rates that includes a shared rate and two secret rates, plus two more rates that measure uncertainty."
The set that includes all possible rate-equivocation pairs is called the capacity-equivocation region.
The capacity-equivocation region is calculated for a special kind of communication system called GMAC. In this system, only one user has secret information to send to another user.
The secrecy capacity region is defined as the set of all achievable rates. This means that user 2 can't know the secret messages sent by user 1.
The capacity and secrecy regions are defined for a special type of communication system with one secret message.
For a secure communication system with two secret messages, we find limits on how well we can hide and send information.
This research uses spread spectrum and signal overlapping methods to protect secret connections from being hacked.

New methods are suggested to create secure connections in flexible optical networks. These connections can be private or public, and the algorithms consider how to use the available spectrum efficiently while keeping the connections safe.
Protecting confidential data using noisy data has gained interest recently.
We want to know how likely certain patterns are in secret data by looking at modified versions of that data.

"This paper suggests a new way to estimate the density of secret data without having the original data. It uses a method called sample-moment-based density approximant, which involves multiplying noisy data to achieve this."
We suggest a system that collects secret information. It uses a computer program that travels to different websites on the internet to gather this information.
Software agents and cryptography help gather and protect secret information.

The client helps identify sensitive information used in software development.
Risky software design elements that could reveal confidential information are identified in two ways: qualitative and quantitative.
